content.description:
From the Hut, a flagged and cairned trail traverses the slopes below Mt. Colin, to a 4th class scramble on treed ledges up to the Hawk-Colin col. 5th class sections are generally avoidable on these treed ledges (300 m, 1.5 hours). From the Hawk-Colin col, scramble 3rd and 4th class terrain to a pedestal leading into an au cheval section. You can build a pin anchor with KBs below the pedestal - follow the intimidating ridge directly, pulling around the ridge (easy fifth class) to gain a reasonable anchor (BD#2 cam and 1/2" angle).

From here a mix of short roping and short pitching on primarily third class terrain (with easy steps of fourth/fifth class) will get you to the top, staying on the ridge. You will reach a steep and overhanging prow with a ledge leading onto the SW face. Follow this ledge for 10-15 m (finger sized cams and fixed piton provide protection) to a 3 piton anchor (Angle, and two LA) in a dirty gully. If you have gone farther than 15 m, you are likely too low on the ridge, and following one of the other tempting ledge systems.

Follow the gully, or the crack to the left (5.6R) past 3 fixed pitons to the crest of the ridge (40 m). Watch for big blocks that can be tempting to pull on: your belayer is in the line of fire. Short rope and short pitch to the summit.

From the summit, descend down the SE ridge to a rap anchor on a slung block (28-30 m rappel). A lower anchor (10 m lower) is available if you only brought a 50 m rope. Continue down the ridge, generally bypassing difficulties on the right. Good time to practice your short roping and terrain belays.

At the Colin-CR6 col, follow cairned scree down to the creek bed, following creek bed to the hut. Standard Rockies pin rack (1-2 LA, 3 KBs, 2 small Angles), 6-8 medium nuts, 0.5-2 BD cams, 4-6 shoulder length slings.
Secluded limestone alpine climbing on one of Jasper's iconic peaks.
